faq.question: Is the bulk image resizer really free?
faq.answer: Yes, completely free with no limits. Resize up to 20 images at a time, as many batches as you need. No signup required.

faq.question: What happens to my original images?
faq.answer: Your original images are never modified or uploaded. All processing creates new resized copies locally in your browser.

faq.question: Can I resize images to different sizes in one batch?
faq.answer: Currently, all images in a batch get the same dimensions. For different sizes, run separate batches or use our individual image resizer.

faq.question: Will this reduce image quality?
faq.answer: Resizing to smaller dimensions maintains quality. Enlarging images may cause pixelation - for significant upsizing, use our AI upscaler instead.

faq.question: What's the maximum image file size?
faq.answer: Individual images up to 10MB are supported. For very large files, consider resizing in smaller batches.

faq.question: Do my photos upload to a server?
faq.answer: No. All processing happens entirely in your browser using the Canvas API. Your photos never leave your device.

limitations: Same dimensions applied to all images in batch
Browser-based processing speed depends on your device

faq.question: How much can I reduce image file sizes?
faq.answer: Typical compression achieves 50-80% file size reduction. Actual savings depend on the original image - already-compressed images see less benefit than uncompressed originals.

faq.question: Will compression damage my image quality?
faq.answer: Our compression is designed to be visually lossless - meaning the file shrinks but the image looks nearly identical. For photos with heavy compression needs, some minor artifacts may appear at extreme settings.

faq.question: Can I compress PNGs with transparency?
faq.answer: Yes, PNG transparency is preserved during compression. Note that JPEGs don't support transparency - they'll get a solid background.

faq.question: What's the difference between this and the upscaler?
faq.answer: The compressor reduces file size without changing dimensions. The upscaler increases dimensions and improves quality. They serve different purposes - use compressor to save space, upscaler to enlarge.

faq.question: Is this better than Photoshop's Save for Web?
faq.answer: Similar quality compression, but our tool handles batches of 20 images at once instead of one by one. Plus, it's free and runs entirely in your browser.

faq.question: Do you permanently delete my images?
faq.answer: Your images never leave your browser in the first place. All compression is local and temporary. Nothing is stored on any server.

limitations: Very compressed images may show quality loss at extreme settings
Compression speed depends on your device and image sizes
